In 2015 hydropower generated 16.6% of the world's total electricity and 70% of all renewable electricity,http://www.ren21.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/GSR_2016_Full_Report_REN21.pdf which continues the rapid rate of increase experienced between 2003 and 2009. Hydropower is produced in 150 countries, with the Asia-Pacific region generating 32 percent of global hydropower in 2010. China is the largest hydroelectricity producer, with {{convert|721|TWh|PJ|abbr=on|order=flip}} of production in 2010, representing around 17% of domestic electricity use. There are now three hydroelectricity plants larger than 10 GW: the [[Three Gorges Dam]] in China, [[Itaipu Dam]] in Brazil, and [[Guri Dam]] in Venezuela.{{cite web |url= http://www.worldwatch.org/node/9527 |title= Use and Capacity of Global Hydropower Increases |publisher= Worldwatch Institute |date= January 2012}} Nine of the [[List of countries by electricity production from renewable sources|worlds top 10 renewable electricity producers]] are primarily hydroelectric, one is wind. ==== Marine energy ==== {{Main article|Ocean energy}} [[Marine energy]], also known as ''ocean energy'' and ''marine and hydrokinetic energy'' (MHK) includes [[tidal power|tidal]] and [[wave power|wave]] power and is a relatively new sector of renewable energy, with most projects still in the pilot phase, but the theoretical potential is equivalent to 4–18 million tonne of oil equivalent (toe). MHK development in U.S. and international waters includes projects using devices such as, wave energy converters in open coastal areas with significant waves, tidal turbines placed in coastal and estuarine areas, in-stream [[turbine]]s in fast-moving [[river]]s, ocean current turbines in areas of strong [[marine current]]s, and [[ocean thermal energy converter]]s in deep tropical waters.{{cite web |title=Tethys |url=http://tethys.pnnl.gov/}} ==== Wind ==== {{Main article|Wind power|Wind power by country}} Wind power is growing at the rate of 17% annually, with a worldwide [[Installed wind power capacity|installed capacity]] of 432,883 megawatts (MW) at the end of 2015,{{cite web |url= http://www.gwec.net/global-figures/graphs/ |title= GWEC Global Statistics |author= Global Wind Energy Council }}Lars Kroldrup. [http://greeninc.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/02/15/gains-in-global-wind-capacity-reported/ Gains in Global Wind Capacity Reported] ''Green Inc.'', 15 February 2010.{{cite web |url= http://www.ren21.net/Portals/97/documents/GSR/GSR2011_Master18.pdf |title= Renewables 2011: Global Status Report |author= [[REN21]] |year= 2011 |page= 15 }} and is widely used in [[Wind power in the European Union|Europe]], [[Wind power in China|Asia]], and the [[Wind power in the United States|United States]].[http://www.gwec.net/uploads/media/07-02_PR_Global_Statistics_2006.pdf Global wind energy markets continue to boom – 2006 another record year] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407175732/http://www.gwec.net/uploads/media/07-02_PR_Global_Statistics_2006.pdf |date=7 April 2011 }} (PDF).{{cite web |url= http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2011/03/wind-power-china-picks-up-paceeu-and-us-fall-but-global-market-grows |title= Wind Power: China Picks Up Pace |first= David |last= Beattie |date= 18 March 2011 |work= Renewable Energy World |publisher= }} Several countries have achieved relatively high levels of wind power penetration, such as 21% of stationary electricity production in [[Wind power in Denmark|Denmark]],{{cite web |publisher= [[World Wind Energy Association]] |title= World Wind Energy Report 2010 |format= PDF |work= Report |date= February 2011 |url= http://www.wwindea.org/home/images/stories/pdfs/worldwindenergyreport2010_s.pdf |accessdate= 30 April 2011 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110904232058/http://www.wwindea.org/home/images/stories/pdfs/worldwindenergyreport2010_s.pdf |archivedate= 4 September 2011 |df= dmy-all }} 18% in [[Wind power in Portugal|Portugal]], 16% in [[Wind power in Spain|Spain]], 14% in [[Wind power in Ireland|Ireland]]{{cite web |url= http://www.eirgrid.com/renewables/ |title= Renewables |publisher= eirgrid.com |accessdate= 22 November 2010 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/61DCEYzn0?url=http://www.eirgrid.com/renewables/ |archivedate= 25 August 2011 |df= dmy-all }} and 9% in [[Wind power in Germany|Germany]] in 2010.{{cite web |url= http://www.ren21.net/Portals/97/documents/GSR/GSR2011_Master18.pdf |title= Renewables 2011: Global Status Report |author= [[REN21]] |year= 2011 |page= 11 }} As of 2011, 83 countries around the world are using wind power on a commercial basis. Continuing strong growth, by 2016 wind generated 3% of global power annually.http://www.bp.com/en/global/corporate/energy-economics/statistical-review-of-world-energy/renewable-energy/wind-energy.html ==== Solar ==== {{Main article|Solar energy|Solar power|Solar power by country}} Solar energy, radiant [[light]] and [[heat]] from the [[sun]], has been harnessed by humans since [[ancient history|ancient times]] using a range of ever-evolving technologies. Solar energy technologies include [[solar heating]], [[solar photovoltaics]], [[concentrated solar power]] and [[solar architecture]], which can make considerable contributions to solving some of the most urgent problems the world now faces. The [[International Energy Agency]] projected that solar power could provide "a third of the global final energy demand after 2060, while CO2 emissions would be reduced to very low levels."http://www.iea.org/Textbase/npsum/solar2011SUM.pdf Solar technologies are broadly characterized as either [[passive solar]] or [[active solar]] depending on the way they capture, convert and distribute solar energy. Active solar techniques include the use of [[photovoltaic system]]s and [[solar thermal collector]]s to harness the energy. Passive solar techniques include orienting a building to the Sun, selecting materials with favorable [[thermal mass]] or light dispersing properties, and designing spaces that [[Ventilation (architecture)|naturally circulate air]]. From 2012 to 2016 solar capacity tripled and now provides 1.3% of global energy.http://www.bp.com/en/global/corporate/energy-economics/statistical-review-of-world-energy/renewable-energy/solar-energy.html ==== Geothermal ==== {{Main article|Geothermal energy|Geothermal power}} [[Geothermal energy]] is used commercially in over 70 countries.{{cite web |publisher= [[MIT]] |title= The Future of Geothermal Energy |url= http://geothermal.inel.gov/publications/future_of_geothermal_energy.pdf |format= PDF |accessdate= 7 February 2007 |archive-url= https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20110310030646/http://geothermal.inel.gov/publications/future_of_geothermal_energy.pdf |archive-date= 10 March 2011 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }} In 2004, {{convert|200|PJ|TWh}} of electricity was generated from geothermal resources, and an additional {{convert|270|PJ|TWh}} of geothermal energy was used directly, mostly for space heating. In 2007, the world had a global capacity for {{val|10|u=GW}} of electricity generation and an additional {{val|28|u=GW}} of [[geothermal heating|direct heating]], including extraction by [[geothermal heat pumps]].{{cite web |url= http://www.ren21.net/globalstatusreport/download/RE_GSR_2006_Update.pdf |format= PDF |publisher= Renewable Energy Policy Network for the 21st century |title= Renewables, Global Status Report 2006 |year= 2006 |accessdate= 3 April 2007 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110718181410/http://www.ren21.net/globalstatusreport/download/RE_GSR_2006_Update.pdf |archivedate= 18 July 2011 |df= dmy-all }}{{cite journal |first1= Ingvar B. |last1= Fridleifsson, |first2= Ruggero |last2= Bertani |first3= Ernst |last3= Huenges |first4= John W. |last4= Lund |first5= Arni |last5= Ragnarsson |first6= Ladislaus |last6= Rybach |date= 11 February 2008 |title= The possible role and contribution of geothermal energy to the mitigation of climate change |conference= IPCC Scoping Meeting on Renewable Energy Sources |editor= O. Hohmeyer and T. Trittin |location= Luebeck, Germany |pages= 59–80 |url= http://iga.igg.cnr.it/documenti/IGA/Fridleifsson_et_al_IPCC_Geothermal_paper_2008.pdf |format= pdf |accessdate= 6 April 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110722030340/http://iga.igg.cnr.it/documenti/IGA/Fridleifsson_et_al_IPCC_Geothermal_paper_2008.pdf |archivedate= 22 July 2011 |df= dmy-all }} Heat pumps are small and widely distributed, so estimates of their total capacity are uncertain and range up to {{val|100|u=GW}}. ==== Bio energy ==== {{Main article|Biomass|Biogas|Biofuel}} Until the beginning of the nineteenth century biomass was the predominant fuel, today it has only a small share of the overall energy supply. Electricity produced from [[biomass]] sources was estimated at 44 GW for 2005. Biomass electricity generation increased by over 100% in Germany, Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland, and Spain. A further 220 GW was used for heating (in 2004), bringing the total energy consumed from biomass to around 264 GW. The use of biomass fires for cooking is excluded. World production of [[Ethanol fuel|bioethanol]] increased by 8% in 2005 to reach {{convert|33|GL|usgal|lk=on}}, with most of the increase in the United States, bringing it level to the levels of consumption in Brazil. [[Biodiesel]] increased by 85% to {{convert|3.9|GL|usgal}}, making it the fastest growing renewable energy source in 2005. Over 50% is produced in Germany. == By country == {{Main article|List of renewable energy topics by country}} {{See also|:category:Energy by country|l1=Energy by country|Worldwide energy supply|List of countries by energy consumption per capita}} {{Pie chart | thumb =right | caption =World total final consumption of 13,699 [[Tonne of oil equivalent|Mtoe]] by region in 2014 (IEA, 2016) | other = | label1 =[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] | value1 =38.4 | color1 =#66CCFF | label2 =Middle East | value2 =5.3 | color2 =#FFFF57 | label3 =Non-OECD Eurasia | value3 =8.2 | color3 =#009a39 | label4 =China | value4 =22.4 | color4 =#de2821 | label5 = Rest of Asia | value5 =12.7 | color5 =pink | label6 =Non-OECD Americas | value6 =4.7 | color6 =#211873 | label7 =Africa | value7 =5.6 | color7 =#ef8e39 | label8 =Bunkers | value8 =2.7 | color8 =#313c42 }} [[File:Global energy consumption.jpg|thumb|right|World energy consumption per capita, 1950-2004]] Energy consumption is loosely correlated with [[Gross National Product#Gross National Product|gross national product]] and climate, but there is a large difference even between the most highly developed countries, such as Japan and Germany with an energy consumption rate of 6 kW per person and the [[Energy use in the United States|United States]] with an energy consumption rate of 11.4 kW per person. In developing countries, particularly those that are sub-tropical or tropical such as India, the per person energy use rate is closer to 0.7 kW. Bangladesh has the lowest consumption rate with 0.2 kW per person. The US consumes 25% of the world's energy with a share of global GDP at 22% and a share of the world population at 4.59%.{{cite web |url= http://esa.un.org/UNPP/ |title= World Population Prospects |publisher= United Nations |accessdate= 7 February 2011 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070321013235/http://esa.un.org/unpp/ |archive-date= 21 March 2007 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }} The most significant growth of energy consumption is currently taking place in China, which has been growing at 5.5% per year over the last 25 years. Its population of 1.3 billion people (19.6% of the world population) is consuming energy at a rate of 1.6 kW per person. One measurement of efficiency is [[energy intensity]]. This is a measure of the amount of energy it takes a country to produce a dollar of gross domestic product. {{multiple image |direction = horizontal |align= center |width1= 255 |width2= 250 |image1=Energy Use per Capita.png |image2=GDP per unit of energy use.png |caption1=The World Bank: Kilograms of oil equivalent (2011) |caption2=The World Bank: PPP $ per kg of oil equivalent (2011) }} {{clear left}} === Oil === {{Main article|Petroleum}} Saudi Arabia, Russia and the United States accounted for 34% of oil production in 2011. Thus the total energy consumption was around 160 PWh (ca {{val|550e15|ul=Btu}}). The efficiency of a typical existing power plant is around 38%.{{cite web |title= Energy efficiency measures and technological improvements. |url= http://www.e8.org/index.jsp?numPage=138 |publisher= e8.org |accessdate= 21 January 2007 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070204112155/http://www.e8.org/index.jsp?numPage=138 |archivedate= 4 February 2007 |df= dmy-all }} Article by group of ten leading electricity companies The new generation of gas-fired plants reaches a substantially higher efficiency of 55%. Coal is the most common fuel for the world's electricity plants.{{cite web |url= http://www.worldcoal.org/assets_cm/files/PDF/coal_fact_card_2006.pdf |archive-url= http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160517000455/http://www.worldcoal.org/assets_cm/files/PDF/coal_fact_card_2006.pdf |dead-url= yes |archive-date= 2016-05-17 |title= Coal Facts 2006 Edition |publisher= [[World Coal Institute]] |format= PDF |date= September 2006 |accessdate= 8 April 2007 }} Another report gives different values for the sectors, apparently due to different definitions. According to this, total world energy use per sector in 2008 was industry 28%, transport 27% and residential and service 36%. Total world energy supply (2008) 143,851 TWh |} ===European Union=== The [[European Environmental Agency]] (EEA) measures final energy consumption (does not include energy used in production and lost in transportation) and finds that the transport sector is responsible for 31.8% of final energy consumption, households 26.2%, industry 25.6%, [[service (economics)|services]] 13.5% and agriculture 2.9% in 2012.European Environmental Agency. {{Cite web|url = http://www.eea.europa.eu/data-and-maps/indicators/final-energy-consumption-by-sector-8/assessment-2|title = Final energy consumption by sector and fuel (CSI 027/ENER 016) - Assessment published Jan 2015|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} Retrieved 21 June 2015. The use of energy is responsible for the majority of greenhouse gas emissions (79%), with the energy sector representing 31%, transport 19%, industry 13%, households 9% and others 7%.Eva Hoos [[European Commission]] 2011. [http://eme2.eu/cust/documentrequest.aspx?DocID=148 A new Directive on Energy Efficiency]. Retrieved 11 October 2011. While [[efficient energy use]] and resource efficiency are growing as public policy issues, more than 70% of [[coal plants]] in the [[European Union]] are more than 20 years old and operate at an efficiency level of between 32–40%.[[European Commission]] 2011. [http://eme2.eu/cust/documentrequest.aspx?DocID=152 Impact Assessment Accompanying the document Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on energy efficiency and amending and subsequently repealing Directives 2004/8/EC and 2006/32/EC]. p. 106. Retrieved 11 October 2011. Technological developments in the 1990s have allowed efficiencies in the range of 40–45% at newer plants. However, according to an impact assessment by the [[European Commission]], this is still below the [[Best available technology|best available technological]] (BAT) efficiency levels of 46–49%. With [[gas-fired power plant]]s the average efficiency is 52% compared to 58–59% with best available technology (BAT), and gas and oil [[Boiler (steam generator)|boiler plants]] operate at average 36% efficiency (BAT delivers 47%). According to that same impact assessment by the [[European Commission]], raising the efficiency of all new plants and the majority of existing plants, through the setting of authorisation and permit conditions, to an average generation efficiency of 51.5% in 2020 would lead to a reduction in annual consumption of {{convert|15|km3|abbr=on}} of natural gas and {{convert|25|Mt|abbr=on}} of coal.
